Ingredients: 

• 500g (about 1.1 pounds) soft tofu, cubed 
• 250g ground pork (you can also use ground chicken or beef) 
• 2-3 cloves garlic, minced 
• 1-inch piece of fresh ginger, grated 
• 2-3 green onions, finely chopped 
• 2-3 tablespoons vegetable oil 
• 2-3 tablespoons Sichuan chili bean paste (doubanjiang) 
• 1 tablespoon Sichuan peppercorns, crushed 
• 1 teaspoon sugar 
• 1 cup chicken or vegetable broth 
• 2-3 tablespoons soy sauce 
• Salt to taste 
• 1-2 tablespoons cornstarch mixed with 2-3 tablespoons water (cornstarch slurry) 
• Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish (optional) 

Procedure: 

1. Start by preparing all the ingredients. Cube the tofu, mince the garlic, grate the ginger, and chop the green onions. 
2. Heat a wok or a large skillet over medium-high heat and add the vegetable oil. 
3. Add the ground pork to the hot oil and stir-fry until it begins to brown, breaking it into small pieces as it cooks. 
4. Add the minced garlic, grated ginger, and chopped green onions to the pork. Stir-fry for a minute or until they become fragrant. 
5. Add the Sichuan chili bean paste (doubanjiang) and crushed Sichuan peppercorns to the pan. Stir-fry for another minute to release their flavors. 
6. Pour in the chicken or vegetable broth and add the sugar and soy sauce. Stir to combine. 
7. Carefully slide the cubed tofu into the pan and gently stir to coat it with the sauce. Be gentle to avoid breaking the tofu. 
8. Simmer the Mapo Tofu for about 5-7 minutes, allowing the tofu to absorb the flavors of the sauce. 
9. Adjust the seasoning with salt if necessary. 
10. Gently stir in the cornstarch slurry to thicken the sauce. Continue cooking for a few more minutes until the sauce reaches your desired consistency. 
11. Serve the Mapo Tofu hot, garnished with fresh cilantro leaves if desired. It's traditionally served with steamed rice. 


Enjoy your homemade Mapo Tofu! This recipe should provide enough for 5 members. Adjust the level of spiciness according to your preference by varying the amount of Sichuan chili bean paste and Sichuan peppercorns.
